ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Only if you are interested in the history of systems and the important papers that made significant contributions to the field of computer systems.
Yes, I would recommand this course to all new system PhD students. It's especially important for system guys to know the why's from history of system study.

Excellent opportunity to get acquainted with current research in systems, especially OS (and more especially involving parallelism, multicore architectures, distributed systems, clouds, etc.). Excellent opportunity to make headway on a systems project. I would highly recommend this course for students particularly interested in operating systems, as well as networks, databases, compilers, and programming languages, though I would caution students that they will need already to have a substantial background in operating systems.

I would recommend this CS722 to graduate students.In this course, students will review the newest and hottest research works, proposes new ideas based on what other people have achieved, and finish a project generally independently.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I know much more from this course than all other courses combined in this semester regarding my field of study.
This course has provided me with knowledge and skills central to my dissertation research.

My research focus on computer networking, a tiny part of computer systems. This course clearly broaden my horizon: I see a larger research community, more interesting problems, and more inspiration ideas.I think this course is one of the most useful courses serving as a foundation of my research.
